section.title: Congruence Operators
section.para: A congruence operator applies a strategy to each direct subterm of a specific constructor. A congruence fails if the application of one the argument strategies fails or if constructor of the operator and that of the term do not match.
section.screen: Plus(Int("14"),Int("3")) stratego> Plus(!Var("a"), id) Plus(Var("a"),Int("3"))
section.para: For each n-ary constructor c declared in a signature, there is a corresponding congruence operator c(s1 , ..., sn ), which applies to terms of the form c(t1 , ..., tn ) by applying the argument strategies to the corresponding argument terms.
The congruence operator is used e.g. in conjunction with the recursive traversal operator to define specific data structure traversals.
Congruences can also be applied to tuples, (s1,s2,...,sn), and lists, [s1,s2,...,sn]. A special list congruence is [] which 'visits' the empty list.
A good example of the use of list congruences is the map(s) strategy.
section.screen:
map(s) = Nil() + Cons(s, map(s))
fetch(s) = Cons(s, id) <+ Cons(id, fetch(s))
filter(s) = Nil + (Cons(s, filter(s)) <+ ?Cons( , <id>); filter(s))

map(s) = [] + [s | map(s)])
fetch(s) = [s | id] <+ [id | fetch(s)]
filter(s) = [] + ([s | filter(s)] <+ ?[ |<id>]; filter(s))

section.title: Generic Traversal: Visiting All Subterms
section.para:
Generic traversal operators Data-type specific traversal requires tedious enumeration of cases
Even if traversal behaviour is uniform
Generic traversal allows concise specification of default traversals
The all(s) strategy transforms a constructor application by applying the parameter strategy s to each direct subterm. An application of all(s) fails if the application to one of the subterms fails.
section.screen: Plus(Int("14"),Int("3")) stratego> all(!Var("a")) Plus(Var("a"),Var("a"))
section.para: Using the all traversal primitive we can define generic traversal strategies like topdown and bottomup.
section.screen: bottomup(s) = all(bottomup(s)); s topdown(s) = s; all(topdown(s)) downup(s) = s; all(downup(s)); s alltd(s) = s <+ all(alltd(s))
const-fold = bottomup(try(EvalBinOp <+ EvalCall <+ EvalIf))
section.para: Example: Desugaring Expressions
section.screen:
DefAnd : And(e1, e2) -> If(e1, e2, Int("0"))
DefPlus : Plus(e1, e2) -> BinOp(PLUS(), e1, e2)
DesugarExp = DefAnd <+ DefPlus <+ ...
desugar = topdown(try(DesugarExp)
IfThen(And(Var("a"),Var("b")), Plus(Var("c"),Int("3"))) stratego> desugar IfThen(If(Var("a"),Var("b"),Int("0")), BinOp(PLUS,Var("c"),Int("3")))

section.title: Generic Traversal: Visiting One Subterm
section.para: The one(s) strategy transforms a constructor application by applying the parameter strategy s to exactly one direct subterm. An application of one(s) fails if the application to all of the subterms fails.
section.screen: Plus(Int("14"),Int("3")) stratego> one(!Var("a")) Plus(Var("a"),Var("a"))
section.para: We can use the one traversal primitive to define a strategy contains, which checks if the current term contains a given term.
section.screen: oncetd(s) = s <+ one(oncetd(s)) oncebu(s) = one(oncebu(s)) <+ s spinetd(s) = s; try(one(spinetd(s))) spinebu(s) = try(one(spinebu(s))); s
contains(|t) = oncetd(?t)
reduce(s) = repeat(rec x(one(x) + s)) outermost(s) = repeat(oncetd(s)) innermostI(s) = repeat(oncebu(s))

section.title: Generic Traversal: Visiting Some Subterms
section.para: The some(s) strategy transforms a constructor application by applying the parameter strategy s to as many direct subterms as possible and at least one. An application of some(s) fails if the application to all of the subterms fails.
section.screen: sometd(s) = s <+ some(sometd(s)) somebu(s) = some(somebu(s)) <+ s
reduce-par(s) = repeat(rec x(some(x) + s))

section.title: Full Term Traversals
section.para: The primitive term traversal operators of Stratego (all, some, one) can be combined with the other control operators in a wide variety of ways to define full term traversals.

section.title: One-Pass traversals
section.para: The most general class of traversals visits every node of a term and applies a transformation to it. The following operators define traversals that apply a strategy s to all nodes of a term.

The strategy topdown(s) first visits a node before it descends to the subterms, bottomup(s) first transforms subterms before applying s to a node, and downup(s) applies the transformation s on the way down and again on the way up. Since s is applied at every subterm, these traversals only succeed if s succeeds everywhere. Therefore, these traversals are typically applied in combination with try or repeat.

The traversals above go through all constructors. If it is not necessary to traverse the entire tree, the following versions of the traversals can be used. They are parameterized with a strategy operator stop that will skip the irrelevant subtrees.

While full traversals visit every node of a tree, partial traversals may stop at some point. An example is the alltd(s) strategy, which stops as soon as it has found a subterm to which s can be succesfully applied.

If s does not succeed, the strategy is applied recursively at all direct subterms. This means that s is applied along a frontier of the subject term. This strategy is typically used in substitution operations in which subterms are replaced by other terms. For example, the strategy alltd(?Var(x); !e) replaces all occurrences of Var(x) by e.
Note that alltd(try(s)) is not a useful strategy. Since try(s) succeeds at the root of the term, no traversal is done.

section.title: Idioms
section.para:
Control over strategy admits wide variety of transformation idioms
Cascading transformations (rewriting, exhaustive application)
simplify = innermost(R1 <+ ... <+ Rn)
innermost(s) = bottomup(try(s; innermost(s)))
Staged transformations (sequence of normal forms)
simplify = innermost(A1 <+ ... <+ Ak) ; innermost(B1 <+ ... <+ Bl) ; ... ; innermost(C1 <+ ... <+ Cm)
Local transformations
transformation = alltd( trigger-transformation ; innermost(A1 <+ ... <+ An) )
alltd(s) = s <+ all(alltd(s))
Application-specific transformations
Recursive patterns
Dynamic programming
